This is a facial recognition task (reception of facial communication); the contrast (self-face vs friend-face) directly probes social communicative perception of faces.
Self-face recognition and the self>friend contrast probe perception/understanding of the self (self-specific activation), meeting the self-perception criteria.

Although the task includes other-person faces, the reported contrast isolates self-specific activation (self>friend) rather than directly measuring perception/representation of others (e.g., friend>self or friend vs stranger).
The task is self- and friend-recognition (name recognition), which is social in nature and probes perception/understanding of self vs other; the Sn–Fn contrast directly measures social processing.

Contrast compares self versus a friend (identity recognition) but does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (e.g., bonding, love, cooperation) or a loved vs stranger comparison; does not meet affiliation/attachment criteria.
Name recognition is a form of reception of non-facial social communication (identity recognition). The Sn–Fn contrast measures social communicative recognition between individuals.
The contrast explicitly compares self (name) to friend, directly probing perception/understanding of the self; meets criteria for self-perception.

Although a friend (an other) is present in the contrast, the Sn–Fn contrast isolates self-specific activation rather than measuring perception/understanding of others; it does not target other-focused processing.

Task involves self- and other-face/name recognition (self vs friend/unfamiliar), i.e., processing social information about self and others; the contrast isolates social processing specific to faces. Satisfies social-related task and measures social processing.

Contrast targets self-specific face processing (self vs friend, masked by face effect) rather than measuring affiliation/attachment or close-relationship bonding; does not test attachment-related constructs.
Face-recognition (reception of facial information) between self, friend, and unfamiliar person fits reception of facial communication; the contrast measures social-communicative processing for faces.
Contrast explicitly targets self-recognition (self-face > friend-face, controlling for name domain), directly measuring perception/understanding of the self.

The analysis isolates self-specific activation (self vs friend, face-specific) rather than primarily measuring representations of others (e.g., friend vs stranger). Thus it does not directly target Perception/Understanding of Others.

Task compares self, friend, and unfamiliar persons (face and name recognition) and examines self-specific activation — a social-related task probing perception/understanding of self and others, so it measures social processing.

The task probes self-recognition and identity (self vs friend vs unfamiliar) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., bonding, loved one vs stranger), so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.
The contrast targets recognition of identities (self/friend/unfamiliar) rather than exchange of social information or communicative behavior; it does not target social communication per se.
The contrast isolates self-specific activation (self vs friend/unfamiliar) in name/face recognition, directly measuring perception and understanding of the self.

Although the design includes other-person (friend, unfamiliar) stimuli, this specific contrast isolates self-specific activation rather than measuring representations or judgments about others (e.g., friend vs stranger), so it does not meet the criteria for perception/understanding of others.

The contrast compares friend versus self across face and name recognition, which is a social-related task involving perception of self and others; it directly measures social processing (self/other distinctions).
The contrast compares friend versus self rather than assessing affiliation/attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger or measures of bonding); it does not specifically target affiliation/attachment.
The task includes face recognition (reception of facial information) and compares friend versus self, so it involves social communication/reception of facial communication.
The contrast involves self-recognition (self vs friend) and thus measures perception and understanding of the self.
The contrast directly involves recognition of a friend (other) versus self, and therefore measures perception and understanding of others.
The task involves face recognition of self, friend, and unfamiliar person—clearly a social-related task. The friend>self contrast measures social processing (self/other social distinction).

The contrast examines friend versus self face recognition but does not explicitly measure affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger) or bonding processes; inclusion criteria for affiliation/attachment are not met.
This is a face-recognition task (reception of facial communication) comparing friend and self; the contrast taps social communication/reception of facial cues regarding others versus self.

Although the task includes self-recognition, the reported contrast is friend>self (friend-specific activation), which does not isolate self-processing per se, so it does not meet the criterion of measuring perception/understanding of self.
The friend>self contrast isolates responses to another person (a friend) relative to self, directly indexing perception/understanding of others.

The task involves recognition of self, friend, and unfamiliar persons (face and name recognition), which is clearly social; the contrast friend vs self measures social processing (self/other recognition).
The contrast compares friend to self during name recognition; it does not target affiliation/attachment processes (e.g., loved one vs stranger) or measure bonding/attachment per se.
The contrast involves recognition of social identity via names (reception of non-facial social communication) comparing friend and self, meeting the social communication construct.

Although the task includes self-recognition conditions, the specific contrast (Friend > Self for names) does not primarily index perception/understanding of the self (it isolates other > self), so it does not satisfy the criterion that the contrast measures self-processing.
The Friend > Self contrast directly probes processing of another person (friend) versus self, and thus measures perception/understanding of others.

Task involves self- and other-face recognition (self, friend, unfamiliar) comparing neural responses to self vs friend vs stranger; this is social processing (perception/understanding of self and others) and measures social processing via face recognition contrasts (including self vs friend). Matches both inclusion criteria: social-related task and measures social processing.

Contrast includes friend vs self and unfamiliar person; involves close social relationship (friend) vs stranger, which indexes affiliation/attachment (loved one vs stranger). The analysis examines friend-specific activation and uses friend–self contrasts, meeting task and measurement criteria.

Face recognition and distinguishing self vs friend vs stranger involves reception of facial communication and social information. The task measures social communication (face reception) and the contrasts (friend vs self vs stranger) assess social communication processes.

The study directly assesses self-face recognition vs others (self vs friend vs unfamiliar), which measures perception and understanding of self (self-recognition). The contrast is self-specific and face-specific, satisfying criteria.

Contrasts involve friend and unfamiliar person vs self, assessing perception/understanding of others. The friend vs unfamiliar and friend vs self contrasts index representations of others, meeting inclusion criteria.

Task contrasts self, friend, and unfamiliar person recognition (face/name), which are social tasks involving self/other processing; the contrast measures social processing related to perception of self and others.

The analysis examines recognition of friend versus self (and interactions with face/name); it does not explicitly target affiliation/attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger or bonding measures), so it does not meet the specified affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

Face and name recognition involve reception of socially relevant facial/name cues; contrasts assess recognition of friend/self which falls under social communication (reception of facial/non‑facial signals).
The contrast directly involves self-recognition (self vs friend/unfamiliar) and thus measures perception and understanding of the self.
Contrasts include friend and unfamiliar person recognition (other-focused processing), indexing perception/understanding of others.

The task contrasts self, friend, and unfamiliar person (face and name recognition)—a social-related task assessing perception and distinctions among social targets. The contrast (common activation to self and friend vs unfamiliar) measures social processing relevant to self/other perception.

The contrast compares familiar (friend) and self versus an unfamiliar person (analogous to loved one vs stranger), which indexes affiliation/attachment-related processing (detection of close vs unfamiliar social targets).

The task includes face recognition (reception of facial communication) and the contrast assesses responses to familiar (self/friend) versus unfamiliar faces/names, fitting social communication (receptive facial communication) criteria.
The analysis involves self-recognition contrasts (masked by self vs control contrasts) and includes self-related processing; thus it measures perception/understanding of self.
The contrast explicitly includes friend and unfamiliar person comparisons (others), measuring perception/understanding of others (familiar vs unfamiliar).
Face recognition of self, friend, and unfamiliar person is a social task probing self/other social processing; the contrast compares social categories (self/friend vs stranger).
Contrast includes friend versus unfamiliar (loved one vs stranger-like) and examines shared activation for self and friend relative to stranger, meeting affiliation/attachment criteria.
This is a face-recognition task (reception of facial communication) comparing self/friend/stranger, so the contrast measures social communication.
The analysis explicitly examines self-face recognition (self vs others), directly probing perception/understanding of the self.
Contrast includes friend and unfamiliar person and compares others to self, addressing perception and understanding of others.
Name-recognition contrasts compare self, friend, and unfamiliar persons — a social task probing self/other processing and social distinction, meeting both social-task and social-processing criteria.
Contrast includes friend versus unfamiliar (loved/known vs stranger) which indexes affiliation/attachment-related processing (social bond), satisfying both inclusion criteria.
Name recognition is reception of non‑facial social communication; the contrast (self/friend vs unfamiliar) maps onto Loved one vs Stranger-type comparisons, meeting criteria.
The analysis explicitly includes self-name recognition (self vs others), indexing perception/understanding of self and thus satisfies the self-related inclusion criteria.
The contrast differentiates friend/unfamiliar persons and therefore measures perception/understanding of others (friend vs stranger), meeting the specified criteria.

The contrast examines self, friend, and unfamiliar person face recognition — a social-related task assessing processing of social identity and self/other distinctions, thus measuring social processing.
The contrast differentiates friend (close other) and unfamiliar person (stranger) and contrasts self/friend vs unfamiliar, aligning with affiliation/attachment comparisons (loved one vs stranger).
This is a face-recognition task (reception of facial communication) comparing self, friend, and stranger, meeting criteria for social communication measures.
The analysis specifically contrasts self-face recognition versus others, directly measuring perception and understanding of the self.
The contrast includes friend and unfamiliar person conditions and compares responses to others (friend vs unfamiliar), thus assessing perception/understanding of others.
Task involves recognition of self, friend, and unfamiliar persons (social recognition) in names and faces, directly measuring social processing.
Contrast compares friend (close other) versus unfamiliar person (stranger), analogous to loved one vs stranger contrasts used to assess affiliation/attachment.
Analysis examines reception of person identity via names (and faces elsewhere in study), i.e. reception of social communication (friend vs stranger, self vs other).
Contrast includes self-name recognition versus others, directly measuring perception/understanding of self.
Contrast includes friend and unfamiliar person conditions, measuring perception/understanding of others (others’ identity).

The SELF-task is an empathy/social task involving processing emotional facial expressions and self/other perspective taking, which clearly measures social processing.

The task probes emotional responses to faces and perspective taking, but does not assess affiliation/attachment, close relationships, or bonding; inclusion criteria for affiliation/attachment are not met.
The task involves processing emotional facial expressions (reception of facial communication), so it measures social communication.
The SELF-task explicitly asks subjects to focus on their own emotional response, which is a direct measure of perception/understanding of self.

This specific analysis contrasts the SELF-task (self-focused emotional response) with baseline and does not measure perception/understanding of others (the OTHER-task would, but it is not the contrast here).
OTHER-task requires evaluating others' emotional states from faces (social/empathic processing). This meets both: task is social-related (I1) and the contrast measures social processing (I2).

Task involves emotion attribution/empathy and facial emotion recognition, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation). Does not meet affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.
OTHER-task is reception of facial communication (evaluating emotional states from faces), satisfying both criteria for social communication (I1 and I2).
Contrast is OTHER vs baseline (evaluation of others), not self-related processing. Does not meet Perception and Understanding of Self criteria.
OTHER-task explicitly measures perception and understanding of others' emotional states from faces, meeting both inclusion criteria (I1 and I2).

The SELF/OTHER task explicitly involves processing social stimuli (emotion-expressing faces) and contrasts self-related vs other-related emotional processing; this directly measures social processing across Perception/Understanding of Self and Others and mirror-neuron activation related to empathy.

The task measures empathy and self/other emotion attribution for faces, not affiliation or attachment (no measures of close relationships, kinship, cooperation/competition, or loved vs stranger contrasts).
The task involves reception of facial communication (recognizing and evaluating emotions from faces) and thus assesses social communication processes relevant to the inclusion criteria.
The SELF-task requires participants to attend to and report their own emotional response to faces, which is a direct measure of perception/understanding of the self (self-related emotional state).
The OTHER-task requires evaluating the emotional state expressed by faces, which directly measures perception and understanding of others’ emotional states.
The task is an empathy/emotion-attribution task comparing SELF (own emotional response to faces) and OTHER processing; this directly measures social processing across sexes.
The contrast examines self-related emotional responses to faces and gender differences in empathy, not measures of affiliation, attachment, or bonding between individuals.
The task involves perception and evaluation of facial emotional expressions (reception of facial communication), so the contrast measures social communication processes.
The contrast specifically involves SELF-task (focusing on one’s own emotional response), directly assessing perception/understanding of the self.

This particular contrast is the SELF-task interaction (female vs male) and does not index perception/understanding of others (OTHER-task); therefore it does not meet criteria for perception of others.
Task contrasts self/other emotional processing (empathy) for faces and the interaction tests gender differences in social-emotional processing, satisfying both criteria.
Task assesses empathy/emotion attribution to faces, not affiliation or attachment (no kinship/relationship/cooperation manipulation), so inclusion criteria not met.
Emotion attribution from faces involves reception of facial communication; the contrast measures social communicative processing across SELF/OTHER, meeting criteria.
SELF-task explicitly measures subjects' own emotional responses (self-perception); the interaction contrasts self-related processing across sexes, meeting criteria.
The specific contrast is for SELF-related processing (SELF_m vs SELF_f interaction) and does not measure perception/understanding of others.
Task assesses empathy/social processing (SELF and OTHER evaluations of emotional faces); the contrast examines OTHER-related processing across genders, so it measures social processing.
Task involves emotion attribution to faces, not affiliation/attachment or bonding (no kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation/competition manipulation).
Task requires reception/recognition of facial emotional expressions (OTHER-task), matching the reception of facial communication subconstruct.
The specific contrast is for the OTHER-task (evaluating others’ emotions), not self-perception/self-related processing.
OTHER-task evaluates others’ emotional states (perception/understanding of others), satisfying criteria for this construct.

The analysis includes a social motor response learning task and reports temporal difference signals during social interaction; it directly measures social processing.

The social motor response learning task involves inference about others' intentions and action understanding (mirror system/frontal operculum), meeting criteria for perception and understanding of others.

The contrast examines Pavlovian vs social tasks and involves inferring others' actions/intentions, not self-perception or self-related judgments.

The social motor response learning task involves inference about other people's intentions and action perception (mirror-operculum activity), meeting criteria for Perception and Understanding of Others.

The contrast is 'Stories > Rest' collapsed across content; it does not specifically isolate social-related processing. Although the study concerns ToM, this particular contrast averages across content types and therefore does not specifically measure Social Processing per the inclusion criteria (I1 and I2 are not clearly satisfied).

The Stories > Rest contrast does not target affiliation/attachment processes (no task contrast indicating loved one vs stranger or similar). The contrast is content-collapsed and therefore does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

The contrast does not specifically measure social communication (no evidence of receptive or productive facial/non-facial communication contrasts); content is collapsed across stories so criteria I1/I2 are not satisfied.

There is no indication the Stories > Rest contrast measures self-perception or self-related judgments; content is collapsed and does not target self-related processes, so inclusion criteria are not met.

Although the broader study concerns theory of mind, this specific Stories > Rest contrast is collapsed across content and does not specifically measure perception/understanding of others (no targeted mental-state reasoning contrast), so it does not satisfy the inclusion criteria.

The contrast 'Stories > Rest' is collapsed across content and reflects general story processing (language/comprehension) rather than a specifically social task or isolated social processing. It does not clearly meet I1 (social-related task specific to social constructs) nor I2 (measures Social Processing).
The stories>rest contrast does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., bonding, loved one vs stranger) and therefore does not satisfy I1 or I2 for Affiliation and Attachment.
The contrast is a general stories vs rest contrast and does not specifically measure social communication (reception/production of facial/non-facial communication), so it does not meet I1 or I2.
The stories>rest contrast does not target self-perception or self-knowledge processes specifically, so it fails to meet I1 and I2 for Perception and Understanding of Self.

Although the overall study concerns theory of mind, this specific contrast is collapsed across content and does not isolate reasoning about others' mental states; it therefore does not meet I1 or I2 for Perception and Understanding of Others.

The contrast 'Cards > Rest' collapses across content (social and non-social) and therefore does not specifically measure social processing or isolate social-related activity (fails I2). Although the study includes social content conditions, this contrast is task-general rather than a social-specific contrast.

The contrast does not target affiliation or attachment processes (no kinship, cooperation, or relationship-specific contrast); it is a general card-response vs rest contrast, so inclusion criteria I1/I2 are not met.

This contrast does not measure social communication (receptive or productive social signaling); it collapses across content and does not isolate communication-related processing, so inclusion criteria I1/I2 are not met.
The contrast is a general task > rest contrast and does not measure self-related processing or self-awareness judgments, so inclusion criteria I1/I2 are not satisfied.
Although the study investigates ToM, this particular contrast collapses across social and non-social content and therefore does not specifically measure perception/understanding of others (fails I2).

Contrast is 'card responses collapsed across content' (task > rest). Because it is collapsed across social and non-social content and is a general task-vs-rest contrast, it does not specifically measure social processing or isolate social-related activity (does not satisfy I1/I2).

The contrast is a general task vs rest collapsed across content and does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (no evidence of cooperation, kinship, loved-one vs stranger contrasts). Does not satisfy I1/I2.

The Wason card task (collapsed across content) is not a social-communication task (no measures of facial, gaze, or communicative exchange) and the contrast does not isolate social-communication processes. Does not satisfy I1/I2.
The contrast reflects general card-task activity vs rest and does not index self-related processing or self-judgment/agency. Does not satisfy I1/I2.

Although the study includes social-exchange conditions that engage ToM, this specific analysis collapsed across content (social and precautionary) and contrasts task vs rest, so it does not specifically measure perception/understanding of others (does not satisfy I1/I2).

The contrast compares social contracts (requiring theory-of-mind/social-exchange reasoning) to precautionary rules; it probes social cognition/ToM, so it is a social-processing task and measures social processing.
Social contract reasoning concerns rule-based social exchange and ToM, not affiliation/attachment (no evidence of bonding, attachment, or close-relationship measures).
The task involves reasoning about social rules and mental states rather than communicative exchange (no measures of facial/expressive or communicative reception/production).
Contrast targets understanding of others’ mental states in social-exchange reasoning, not self-perception or self-knowledge.

Social-contract reasoning explicitly requires reasoning about others’ intentions and mental states (ToM), and the study reports activation of ToM-related regions for social contracts vs precautions, satisfying perception/understanding of others.
The analysis concerns reasoning about social exchange and explicitly engages theory-of-mind processes; it is a social-related task measuring social processing.
Social exchange (cooperation) is the focus of the task (Wason social contract), matching examples of cooperation and thus measuring affiliation/attachment-related processes.
The task involves exchange-related social reasoning (cooperation/social exchange), which fits the social communication examples (cooperation/competition) in the inclusion criteria.
The contrast probes understanding of others' mental states in social exchange rather than self-related processes; it does not assess perception/understanding of the self.
The study explicitly reports activation of ToM areas when interpreting social exchange rules, indicating measurement of understanding others' mental states.
Contrast compares social exchange (social contracts) vs precautionary rules; involves Theory-of-Mind reasoning about others’ desires/goals—measures social processing.
Task concerns abstract social-contract reasoning, not measures of affiliation, attachment, or close relationships.
Contrast probes reasoning about social rules/ToM rather than communicative exchange (faces, gaze, or explicit communication); does not target social communication subconstructs.
Task requires reasoning about others (social exchange) rather than self-related processing or self-knowledge.
Social exchange reasoning explicitly involves understanding others’ mental states (ToM), matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

The analysis contrasts social contracts (social exchange) and engages Theory of Mind reasoning about others’ mental states; it is a social-related task and directly measures social processing related to understanding others.
The task assesses social exchange/ToM reasoning rather than affiliation, attachment, or close-relationship processes; it does not measure bonding/attachment constructs.
The analysis concerns reasoning about social exchange and mental states (ToM), not communication behaviors (facial/exchange signals or production/reception of communicative acts).
The task examines reasoning about others (social exchange/ToM), not self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge.
The analysis involves representing and reasoning about others’ mental states (Theory of Mind) during social contract tasks, matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

Contrast examines precautionary (non-ToM) reasoning greater than social contract reasoning; the analysis identifies regions activated for precautions, which the authors state do not require theory-of-mind/social processing. Therefore it does not measure social processing per the inclusion criteria.
The analysis contrasts precautionary reasoning with social contracts and does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger).
The task and contrast probe reasoning about rules (precautions vs social contracts), not exchange of social communication (facial/non‑facial receptive/expressive communication).
The contrast does not involve self‑referential processing or judgments about the self; it contrasts types of rule reasoning (precautions vs social contracts).

The precautions > social contracts contrast highlights precautionary reasoning, which the authors report does not require ToM/understanding others; therefore it does not measure perception/understanding of others (mental states).
This contrast isolates precautionary reasoning (non-social conditional rules). The study states precautionary rules do not require ToM/social processing, so it does not measure social processing.
The task contrasts precautions (non-social reasoning) and does not assess affiliation or attachment-related processes or comparisons (e.g., loved one vs stranger).
Precautionary rule reasoning does not involve social communication (facial, verbal, or nonverbal exchange) and thus does not meet the social communication criteria.
The contrast pertains to reasoning about precautionary rules, not self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge processes.

The analysis targets precautionary (non-ToM) reasoning; the study specifically notes ToM/understanding others is not engaged for precautions, so it does not measure perception/understanding of others.

This contrast (Precautions > Social Contracts) isolates neural activity for precautionary reasoning, which the authors state does not require theory-of-mind or social-exchange processing. It does not measure social processing or a social-related task, so it does not satisfy the inclusion criteria.

The task contrasts precautionary rules versus social contract rules; the Precautions > Social Contracts contrast does not probe affiliation or attachment processes (e.g., bonding, cooperation) and thus does not meet the inclusion criteria.
The contrast targets logical reasoning about precautionary rules rather than exchange of social information or communicative behaviors; it does not measure social communication.

The Precautions > Social Contracts contrast examines precautionary reasoning (not self-referential processing, agency, or self-knowledge), so it does not meet criteria for perception/understanding of self.

The contrast isolates precautionary reasoning, which the study specifies does not require reasoning about others' mental states (ToM). Therefore it does not measure perception/understanding of others.

The contrast is for 'precautions' (precautionary rules). The study states ToM and social processing were not engaged for precautionary reasoning; this is a non-social reasoning condition, so it does not measure social processing (fails I1/I2).
Precautionary rule reasoning does not involve affiliation or attachment constructs (no kinship, cooperation, loved-one vs stranger contrasts); does not meet inclusion criteria I1/I2.
The task contrasts precautionary reasoning, not social communication (no reception/production of facial or non-facial communication); does not satisfy I1/I2.
The precaution condition involves logical reasoning about rules rather than self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency; it does not meet I1/I2 for Perception and Understanding of Self.
The study explicitly reports that ToM/understanding of others was not activated for precautionary rules; this contrast does not measure perception/understanding of others (fails I1/I2).
The analysis examines reasoning about social exchange (social contracts) and engages theory-of-mind processes; this is a social-related task and measures social processing.
The task probes reasoning about social-exchange rules and ToM rather than measuring affiliation, attachment, or relationship bonding; it is not assessing attachment/affiliation constructs directly.
The analysis does not assess social communication (e.g., receptive/expressive facial or non‑facial communication); it focuses on rule reasoning and ToM, not communicative exchange.
The task concerns reasoning about others' mental states in social exchange, not self‑perception, self‑knowledge, or agency.
The analysis specifically involves understanding others' mental states (Theory of Mind) during social-exchange reasoning, matching Perception and Understanding of Others.

Contrast 'Descriptives > Precautions' compares descriptive to precautionary rule reasoning; neither condition is a social-related task (precautionary rules are non-social; descriptive rules here are not social exchange). Does not measure Social Processing.
The contrast does not involve affiliation/attachment tasks (no kinship, cooperation, loved-one vs stranger comparisons); it contrasts rule types (descriptive vs precautionary).
The task contrasts rule reasoning types and does not probe social communication (no facial/communicative reception or production).
The contrast does not assess self-perception or self-related judgments; it contrasts descriptive vs precautionary reasoning.

Although the study examines ToM for social exchange generally, this specific contrast (Descriptives > Precautions) does not target understanding others’ mental states; precautionary and descriptive rules are non-social here.

Although social exchange involves cooperation, the task contrasts reasoning about social contracts rather than measuring affiliation/attachment or bonding per se; it does not target attachment or close-relationship measures.

The contrast concerns understanding others’ mental states in social-exchange contexts, not self-awareness, monitoring, or self-knowledge, so it does not meet Perception and Understanding of Self criteria.

The task is a valence classification of agentic vs communal words and does not involve social communication (receptive or productive communicative behavior).

The contrast focuses on agency vs communion word processing rather than representing or reasoning about others' mental states; it does not measure perception/understanding of others.

The contrast ‘Words > Faces’ compares responses to word stimuli versus face stimuli and is primarily a language vs perceptual contrast. Although the overall study probes communicative actions, this specific contrast does not specifically measure social processing or a social-related task as defined by the annotation (e.g., social interaction, perception/understanding of others). It therefore does not satisfy I1 or I2.

There is no indication that the ‘Words > Faces’ contrast measures affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship scenarios, cooperative/competitive interactions). It does not satisfy the inclusion criteria for Affiliation and Attachment.

The contrast contrasts words and faces and does not specifically index social communicative behavior (reception/production of facial or non-facial communication). Even though the study investigates speech acts, this particular Words > Faces contrast does not directly measure social communication as required by I1/I2.
The contrast does not involve judgments about the self, agency, or self-knowledge. It does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self and therefore fails the inclusion criteria.

Although faces can relate to perception of others, the contrast ‘Words > Faces’ is not a targeted measure of perceiving or reasoning about others’ mental states or actions; it contrasts word processing with face processing and does not meet the inclusion criteria for Perception and Understanding of Others.

The contrast compares competitive vs noncompetitive social contexts (Competition > No competition), clearly a social task and directly measures social processing related to social interaction and feedback.

Competition is explicitly a social interaction paradigm listed in the examples (Cooperation and competition); the contrast measures behavior and neural responses related to that social context, satisfying affiliation/attachment inclusion.
Competition is an example task for Social Communication in the criteria. The contrast probes socially relevant feedback and interaction, meeting the communication construct.

Cooperation/competition is listed as an example task for Perception and Understanding of Self; the contrast involves social-referencing and self-related evaluative processes during competition, satisfying the construct criteria.

Competition involves assessing others’ actions and social context; examples list competition as relevant to Perception and Understanding of Others, and the contrast captures those social-comparative processes.
The analysis contrasts competitive vs noncompetitive learning environments (social competition), which is a social-related task and directly measures social processing differences between conditions.
Competition is explicitly listed as an example task for affiliation/attachment constructs (social bonds/interaction); the contrast directly compares competitive vs noncompetitive contexts.
The task involves social interaction (competition) and thus measures social communication-related processes between participants and/or about others.

The contrast 'Select > content' appears to index participants selecting articles to read (self-focused selection) relative to content baseline, not a social/sharing condition. Although the study includes sharing contrasts, this specific contrast does not target social processing.

Sharing information is an exchange of socially relevant information (production of non-facial communication), so the contrast measures social communication.

The paper reports involvement of self-related processing and self-reflection in decisions to select and share articles, and that these regions showed greater activity in the sharing condition, so the contrast measures aspects of self-perception/processing.

The study explicitly reports perspective-taking/processing of others in relation to sharing decisions and greater activity when considering sharing with other people, so the contrast measures perception/understanding of others.

Share > select contrasts considering sharing articles with others versus selecting them to read; task is social and the contrast measures social processing (sharing, connecting with others). The study reports engagement of social/valuation/self-related networks when sharing.

Selecting articles to read for oneself does not measure affiliation or attachment processes (no bonding, kinship, cooperation/competition, or related contrasts).
The Select condition does not involve exchange of social information or communicative behaviors; it reflects a personal choice rather than social communication.

The Select analysis concerns personal reading decisions rather than representing or reasoning about others' mental states; perception/understanding of others was linked to sharing, not Select.

The analysis contrasts decisions to share articles with others and activity scaled with preferences for sharing; the task is explicitly social (sharing with other people) and measures social processing (perspective-taking, self-related and other-related valuation).

The task involves sharing news articles but does not target affiliation/attachment (e.g., close relationships, bonding, cooperation) or contrasts like loved one vs stranger; criteria for affiliation/attachment are not met.

The study reports engagement of self-related processing and self-reflection associated with decisions to select and share articles, indicating the analysis measures perception/understanding of the self.
The analysis involves considering sharing with other people and the abstract reports activity related to taking the perspective of others, meeting criteria for perception and understanding of others.

The contrast compares collaboratively generated labels (a social learning/communication context) to arbitrarily assigned labels, directly probing social processes. The task involves interaction and communicative retrieval, and the abstract reports engagement of mentalizing/social brain regions.

The Partnering analysis is a two-person joint-action task (leading, following, mutual) involving interpersonal coordination and social roles; it clearly measures social processing (self- vs other-oriented social interaction).

Although participants are interacting dyadically (dancers), the contrasts probe joint-action roles (leading/following/mutual) and not affiliation/attachment or bonding per se; the analysis does not target affiliation measures or loved-one vs stranger contrasts.

Partnering requires exchange of socially relevant information via nonverbal/haptic cues and role signals (leader/follower), so it reflects social communication processes (non-facial, nonverbal communication).

The abstract explicitly states Leading is associated with self-orientation and involves processes related to agency and self-monitoring (motor planning, sequencing), so the contrast measures perception/understanding of the self.

The paradigm is joint improvised movement/dance and not designed to measure affiliation or attachment (no contrast targeting loved vs stranger, cooperation framed as attachment).

Joint action with role alternation requires nonverbal exchange and coordination; the Following contrast reflects receptive/production of non-facial communication (motion cues) and social coordination.
The Following condition is externally oriented and the contrast targets sensory/proprioceptive and social cognition processes rather than self-perception/agency.
Following emphasizes action perception, motion tracking, and understanding others’ actions/states, matching perception/understanding of others.

The task is a two-person joint-action (leading/following/mutual) involving social interaction; the mutual condition specifically engages mentalizing and social reward processes per the abstract, so it measures social processing.

The improvisation analysis focuses on motor planning and working memory during joint action rather than explicit measures of self-perception, agency, or self-knowledge; it does not meet the perception-of-self inclusion criteria.

While joint action involves attending to a partner, the reported improvisation contrast emphasizes motor-planning and working-memory rather than explicit perception/understanding of others' mental states or action-perception contrasts required by this annotation.

The contrast examines joint improvisation and role-related motor/planning processes rather than self-focused perception or judgments about one’s traits or internal states (agency/self-knowledge not the primary target).

The analysis models brain responses as reactions to the partner's behavior during interaction; this targets perception/action understanding of others (action perception/understanding others).

The task involves interactive exchanges (cooperation/competition) and measures responses during social interaction, matching social communication criteria.

TEQ is an empathy measure and the regressions link questionnaire scores to socioemotional task activation, which indexes perception/understanding of others (mental/emotional states).

The study explicitly investigates empathy and anxiety during socioemotional processing; the analysis regresses STAI (anxiety) scores against neural responses from socioemotional tasks, which constitute social processing.

No evidence that the analysis/task specifically targeted affiliation or attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). The analysis is a general anxiety questionnaire regression during socioemotional processing, not specific to affiliation.

Prisoners' dilemma is a social decision-making task; the analysis measures social behavior/social cognition during the task, satisfying both social-related task and measurement of social processing.

The task involves cooperative/competitive social interactions (examples listed for this construct) and thus assesses social communication aspects relevant to the inclusion criteria.
The prisoners' dilemma focuses on social decision-making about others rather than explicit self-perception or self-knowledge; it does not specifically measure Perception and Understanding of Self.

Prisoners' dilemma is a social task probing social behaviour; the analysis explicitly examines social behaviour and neural correlates, so it measures social processing.

Prisoners' dilemma requires reasoning about others' likely actions/intentions (cooperation/competition); the analysis of social behaviour and medial prefrontal activation is consistent with perception/understanding of others.

The prisoners' dilemma is a social task assessing social behaviour and cognitions. The CONTROLS per-group fMRI analysis measures neural responses during this social task, so it satisfies both I1 (social-related task) and I2 (measures Social Processing).

The prisoners' dilemma operationalizes cooperation/competition, a form of affiliation/attachment-related social interaction. The CONTROLS analysis of the game therefore meets I1 (task type) and I2 (measures Affiliation and Attachment).
The task involves exchange of socially relevant information (cooperation/competition decisions), fitting Social Communication. The per-group analysis in controls assesses this, satisfying I1 and I2.

Although cooperation/competition tasks can sometimes probe self-related processing, the presented analysis is a general per-group contrast of the prisoners' dilemma and does not specifically target self-awareness or explicit self-judgments. Thus it does not clearly meet the I2 requirement for Perception and Understanding of Self.

The prisoners' dilemma requires representing and responding to others' intentions and actions (understanding mental states), so the controls' fMRI analysis measures Perception and Understanding of Others, meeting I1 and I2.
The analysis examines group differences during a prisoners' dilemma task (a social interaction), so it assesses social processing across groups.
The prisoners' dilemma operationalizes cooperation/competition (affiliation/attachment-related behavior); the main effect of group compares this social-affiliative task across groups.
The task involves social interaction (cooperation/competition) relevant to social communication processes; the contrast assesses these processes across groups.

The prisoners' dilemma is primarily an interpersonal decision-making task and the reported analysis is a group main effect; there is no indication the contrast specifically measures self-related perception/knowledge (agency or self-knowledge).
The task requires reasoning about others' choices/intentions (cooperation/competition), so group differences in task activation likely reflect perception/understanding of others.

The analysis is from a prisoners' dilemma fMRI task measuring social behaviour; the main effect of condition assesses social-related processes. Satisfies task is social-related and measures social processing.
Prisoners' dilemma operationalizes cooperation/competition (affiliation/attachment-related) and the main condition contrast captures affiliation/attachment behavior.
Cooperation/competition tasks are listed as examples for social communication measures; the prisoners' dilemma main effect likely engages social communicative/interactive processes.

The main effect of condition in a prisoners' dilemma reflects interactive social behavior (cooperate/defect) rather than explicit self-awareness or self-judgment measures; it does not specifically measure perception/understanding of self.

The prisoners' dilemma requires reasoning about others (cooperation/competition) and the main condition contrast likely taps perception/understanding of others' intentions; meets task and measurement criteria.

The analysis is an ROI group effect from participants playing a prisoners' dilemma (a social decision-making task). This is a social-related task and the contrast measures social processing (group differences in task-related activation).
Prisoners' dilemma is a cooperation/competition paradigm relevant to affiliation and attachment; the ROI group contrast measures these social interactions between groups.

The task (prisoners' dilemma) assesses social interaction and exchange of socially relevant information (cooperation/competition), and the ROI group effect measures this social communication-related processing.

Cooperation/competition tasks can engage self-related processes (agency, self-monitoring) and the analysis contrasts group activation during the social task, meeting criteria for perception/understanding of self.

The prisoners' dilemma requires representing and reasoning about others' choices/intentions; the ROI group effect measures neural responses to those processes, meeting criteria for perception/understanding of others.
